Our previous molecular epidemiology studies suggested that among Cypriot subjects, 1b and 3a were the most predominant subtypes, followed by 1a. Specifically, 3a was the most prevalent (57%) among people who inject drugs (PWID) and 1b among the general population. For people who inject drugs, the 2k/1b recombinant type that has been previously described in Russia was also detected
6 .The global distribution of subtypes 1a and 1b has likely been shaped by the dissemination of blood and blood products after the Second World War
7 , while the distribution of genotype 3 is likely a result of the mobility of PWID and drug trafficking
8â€“ 10 . In Cyprus, HCV infection from intravenous drug use is associated with each prevalent subtype
11 . With these transmission mechanisms, local and global human movement primarily drive the phylogeography of HCV due to the evolutionary dynamics of the virus
12 .
